abstract.p: Charles V Angelo letter on Michael Korda's May 7 travel article describes experiences at African lodges and campsites; photo

block.p: To the Editor: Michael Korda's article ''Lodges in Africa That Make a Case for Settling In'' (May 7) rang true with my own experiences. To the Editor: Michael Korda's article ''Lodges in Africa That Make a Case for Settling In'' (May 7) rang true with my own experiences. Having traveled to Kenya and Tanzania four times in the past 20 months, also with Abercrombie & Kent, I am now preparing for a five-week trip to the Masai Mara for the great migration this summer.

I personally prefer the unfenced, tented camps, e.g., Little Governor's on the Masai Mara, which, while a bit more rustic, still offer surprising luxury with a variety and quality of food that is amazing for such a remote destination.

In addition, you get the opportunity to sleep under canvas and listen to the sounds of elephants and hippos munching feet away from your tent. The experience is amazing and provides a strange sense of security. Not a night will go by without having your sleep interrupted, as the urge to observe these marvelous animals outside your tent by only the light of the moon is irresistible.
